abstracts.cdata!:
The Municipal Sector Investment Project
            has been rated satisfactory, with good performances from
            both the Bank and the Borrower, due largely to
            pre-established institutional arrangements. Although
            preparation was delayed, coupled with extreme optimism on a
            successful local tax reform, drastic changes in the fiscal
            system promoted the development of the project, and its
            efficient disbursement demonstrates the usefulness of these
            changes. Lessons show that sustainable municipal investments
            and finances are reliable on municipal resources, and,
            autonomous local governments with appropriate human
            resources, in addition to a financial institution providing
            technical and financial assistance. This sustainability
            requires long-term strategic planning to allow progress
            continuity. With the introduction of the local tax reform,
            whose effects are only expected within 3 years, issues
            exist, which undermine Government decentralization. A strong
            political will is required for local tax reforms to succeed,
            thus, the next operation will need to address these issues.
            A realistic view of the Government's willingness to
            decentralize needs to be assessed, for autonomous local
            governments to deliver effective local services, and,
            improve management and development priorities. Local finance
            and management issues should have been addressed in balance
            with restructuring issues.
